content: In FY2009, federal spending on programs for people with low income was almost $708 billion, with most of the growth related to the recession and policy responses. Four programs accounted for almost 60% of total spending, and 10 programs accounted for more than 75%. Federal programs for low-income populations accounted for almost 60% of total spending, with 10 programs making up over 75%. Unlike social insurance programs like Social Security and Medicare, these programs are funded through general revenues and provide benefits to those with limited income. Social insurance programs aim to protect American workers universally against lost wages and work-related benefits, while programs for low-income individuals specifically target those in need. Federal programs for low-income populations provide benefits and services to those with limited income, aiming to address economic disadvantage through cash or noncash assistance, education, training, and community support. These programs target basic needs like food, housing, and healthcare, as well as improving employability and earnings capacity. They may also incentivize participation in work or training activities and provide assistance to communities with low tax capacities. Federal programs for low-income populations offer diverse benefits and services, created independently and evolving over time in response to societal factors.
